reviewText: "Noroi" is presented as an investigative documentary from a now missing television ghost hunter, so while there is some amateur shaky camera work during the more action orientated climax a majority of the movie is interestingly made up of clips from investigations, variety television shows, news reports, and interviews.  There is even a subtle musical score, appropriately simple enough to pass off as a modest television presentation but also effective enough at setting the spooky mood.  The narrative is fairly complex as our protagonist travels all over Tokyo interviewing a large memorable cast of TV personalities, psychics, experts, lunatics, and other witnesses to the supernatural. Gradually it becomes clear there is a common thread connecting these seemingly non-related but escalating paranormal curiosities, establishing an alluring mystery that drives the narrative  in the second act.The huge cast all give credible convincing performances, even the more amusing weirdoes are no more over the top than the average television psychic. The supernatural occurrences are creepy but fairly low key with the cameras and audio recorders not catching anything you wouldn't see on your average "true haunting" program; ultimately, it is the unbearable dread generated by the growing sense that something evil is closing in on the characters that makes this film so effectively chilling. Very subtle CGI is used maybe once or twice, but its not really noticable enough to break the suspension of believe.  While this is a mostly bloodless affair, the brief violence and explicit supernatural activity that shockingly erupts in the final act is a satisfying payoff for the film's unusual lengthy build.-Dan S of dangerdiablogik.com
summary: A Very Complex and Creepy Mokumentary

reviewText: If you like Blair Witch, Cloverfield, Paranormal Activity or other such movies, you will want to see this one.  It has great scary atmosphere, slightly diminished by a somewhat ridiculous super-psychic male character in tin foil but still required viewing for fans of this sort of "point of view horror" film.

reviewText: Very good movie...  I just felt like adding that it's a Japanese horror movie, not Korean.  Good nonetheless.  It's very creepy and the environment it creates is disturbing to say the least.  I recommend it to any horror fan.

reviewText: I'm mostly posting another review on this page to show support for releasing this outstanding film stateside.  The DVD listed on this page is a region 3 DVD and will not play on U.S. DVD players.  The copy I have is a CD-R with poor quality, although in some cases that makes the film look more like a "found footage" flick and kinda adds to the atmosphere.  Regardless, I'd love to see it on DVD or Blu-Ray.There's no getting around the fact this movie obviously is fake and these events did not happen. It doesn't pull a Blair Witch Project or a Paranormal Activity and try to market itself as though it could be "real."  The film revolves around telekinesis as a main concept.  This does not make the movie any less terrifying.What Noroi has that many other films of this type don't is consistency.  Many other films feature too much talking, too many jump scares, too many professional-looking shots for a "home-made" movie, or a combination of the above.  Noroi never falls into any such traps.  It uses the documentary angle effectively to tell the story about the curse and its rituals, but it never relies too much on talking to move the story forward and doesn't need jump scares to be an effective film, because it's just so damn creepy it doesn't need it.I would definitely say this and Lake Mungo are the two best mockumentary horror films I've ever seen, but Lake Mungo had too much talking in the middle of the film, while Noroi built up suspense and kept its creepy factor up relentlessly without ever giving the viewer time to relax.  Alas, the director of this film went on to direct Carved, and needless to say, I don't think he'll ever top Noroi.  But if Carved could get a stateside release, Noroi definitely should.
summary: The greatest mockumentary horror film of all time

reviewText: I first found it and watched it on YouTube. It was a movie I never heard of so I gave it a chance because it looked creepy(I love scary movies). I must say it became one of my favorite movies EVER. The story is great, very "it-could-really-happen" feeling to it, and  the performances are perfect.
